ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I understood a lot more about the different events and aspects of the trans-atlantic slave trade.

I learned about an area of history that I had not previously explored, and I got to poke around the Yale archives for the primary source exercises. The four oral presentations throughout the semester were also a nice opportunity to practice more formal academic speaking and presentations with my peers.
I gained a deep understanding of the fundamental principles and advanced concepts of slavery allowing me to grasp complex ideas and their practical applications.
Slavery and the slave trade in Africa
Learned about the slave trade from a new perspective (that of multiple African nations and European traders, as opposed to the purely American-centric view that I was previously familiar with)

I learned a lot about the nuances of the internal slave trade in Africa and, importantly, how the transatlantic slave trade impacted life and politics on the continent. As the course granted me insight into a period of history about which I previously knew little, Professor Harms also taught us how to search for and meaningfully analyze primary source documents for our final project.
I learned so much about slavery and the slave trade in Africa. I also learned how to interpret and engage meaningfully with primary sources (both published and unpublished).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course did not ask students to really think critically about any of the material we read or engaged with. I was disappointed by the lack of student engagement, and I think that was partially because the professor did not push us to ask broader questions or go beyond facts and historical trends.
The class was very contextual
Fewer readings

The strengths of the course were its content and the final primary source activity. It was incredibly interesting to hear which primary sources my classmates were studying, and I enjoyed analyzing firsthand accounts for my final project. The weaknesses of the course were some of the course readings and the brevity of our discussions. I thought that the readings at the beginning of the semester were less engaging than the books Professor Harms assigned at the end of the term (they were more dynamic articles and books rather than textbook entries), and I often felt that we could have gone more in-depth with our seminar discussions. We often ended class early when I felt like we could have talked about the readings in much greater nuance.

Strengths: really knowledgeable instructor; great readings; seminar structure was unique but facilitated learning really well; workload was just the right balance of readings and assignments.

Weaknesses: none.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to another student. This class dives into a very uncomfortable topic but is able to teach it in a way where it is engaging and insightful.

Probably not. I do not feel like I gained much from this course, besides a pre-industrial credit and finding a few cool things in the archive. Unless you really just want some factual knowledge of this subject, and don't care about thinking critically about any historical analysis, I would recommend taking a different pre-industrial course.
Yes, this is because if provides a comprehensive overview of the slave trade from different pespective
This is the course you want to take trust me
Yes!

I would recommend this course to another student for its content, but I would also advise them that they will gain the most out of the readings from their own exploration rather than any in-class discussion. Although the content is fantastic and incredibly important, the class itself could be a bit disorganized and less engaging than the material itself.
Yes! You learn new information about slavery that is not taught.
YES! It is a really great way to learn about a variety of aspects of slavery and the slave trade in Africa.
